H0.text: The solute is the 20 grams of sugar that was dissolved in 200 mL of water to form the sugar‑water solution whose density the student measured and recorded.

H1.text: The sugar in this investigation is undergoing chemical change, as the student measured the density of 200 mL of water, then dissolved 20 g of sugar into it, and recorded the density of the resulting sugar‑water solution in a table.

H2.text: The solvent is the sugar that was dissolved in the 200 mL of water in this investigation.

H3.text: Changing from a solid to a gas is the state change that the sugar undergoes in the investigation where 200 mL of water was measured, 20 g of sugar was dissolved, and the density of the resulting sugar‑water solution was determined and recorded.

A4.text: sugar water, which contains dissolved sucrose

A5.text: the substance that is more often used as a solvent is normally designated as the solvent (in this example, water)
